Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation2: The nursing assistant is assigned to a patient in critical condition whose vital signs must be monitored every few minutes.
Story: I glanced at my watch, heart pounding. My shift as a nursing assistant was in full swing, and Mrs. Carter’s blood pressure had been dangerously low all morning. I was supposed to check her vitals every five minutes, no exceptions. But just as I finished recording her last reading, my phone buzzed with a text from my stepbrother, Max. “About to try the new trick. Come watch?” I looked out the window and saw him at the top of the steep ramp, skateboard in hand, helmet slightly askew. He’d promised to wait for me, but I knew how impatient he could be. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But if I left Mrs. Carter, even for a few minutes, I’d be neglecting my duty—and risking her safety. My hands shook as I weighed the demands pulling me in opposite directions, feeling the pressure of both roles squeezing my chest.
